p: A. clypeolata has not been investigated thoroughly yet, with the exception of its antioxidant and antimicrobial properties [ 96, 98]. In this study, the EO of A. clypeolata exhibited the strongest activity against K. pneumoniae and P. aeruginosa, even stronger than the antibiotic Ampicilin, which was used as the standard for comparison. A. clypeolata EO showed lower activity against Gram-positive S. aureus, but still stronger than Ampicilin, while E. coli was the most resistant to the oil [ 96]. Indeed, previous study on Cinnamomum longepaniculatum leaf EO has shown that its compounds have excellent antibacterial activities, and the antibacterial mechanism of 1,8-cineole against E. coli and S. aureus might be attributed to its hydrophobicity [ 99].
